author: Valerie Chaille
title: ETFs Are Getting More Popular—and More Complex
text:
1 COMMENTS According to an annual study by the Financial Planning Association and Journal of Financial Planning, exchange-traded funds have become the preferred investment vehicle of financial advisers—with more than 80% of advisers using and recommending ETFs for clients. That’s more than any other product, including mutual funds.
Journal Report Insights from The Experts Read more at WSJ.com/WealthReport More in Wealth Management Money and College: The Crucial Questions for Parents and Children More U.S. Students Look to College Abroad Why Peer Pressure May Not Help You Save More for Retirement When Millennials Move Back Home Mistakes Charitable Startups Make In addition to the diversification benefits ETFs offer, their tax efficiency also has helped them grow in popularity since 2006, when just 40% of survey participants used them. Because ETF holdings are based on an index, there is very little turnover in the underlying investments. That means unlike mutual funds, whose makeup is determined and adjusted by a manager, there isn’t much trading within ETFs that would trigger capital-gains taxes.
Many investors like that they can look at an index and know, in real time, what securities an ETF is holding. They also like that ETFs are liquid assets. Because ETFs are traded intraday just like stocks, investors don’t have to wait for pricing at the end of the trading day.
Still, the increasing diversity and complexity of ETFs is something that investors and advisers need to monitor closely.
From smart-beta ETFs to leveraged and derivative-based products, there are many newer ETFs on the market today that engage in some level of active management.
It’s safe to assume that the ETF space is one that will continue to grow and evolve. As it does, investors need to keep educating themselves and adjusting their own strategies accordingly.
Ms. Chaille is director of practice management for the Financial Planning Association and the founder and president of SummitView Financial in Indianapolis. She can be reached at reports@wsj.com .
